head.title: Relics of Czech Modernism From Between the World Wars

hedline.hl1: Relics of Czech Modernism From Between the World Wars

block.p: Prague Kolektiv, a shop specializing in Czech furniture, glassware and lighting from the 1920's and 30's, opened yesterday in Dumbo, Brooklyn. The owners, below, are Barton Quillen (seated), an American, and Giovanni Negrisin, an Italian, who met in Prague about 10 years ago. Both were collecting pieces from what they saw as a pivotal moment in design: the period in Czech history and culture that fell between the two world wars. ''The whole country was embracing modernity at the time as a way of expressing participation in a new world, a free society,'' Mr. Quillen said.

Shown with him is a front-entrance shoe station from the early 1930's. It is chrome and burled walnut and priced at $3,000. A child's rocking toy, top, made with chrome and lacquered wood, is also from the early 1930's and also $3,000. A crystal decanter with six glasses, inset, is $700. Prague Kolektiv is at 143-B Front Street (Jay Street), Brooklyn; (718)260-8013.
